Udawalawe National Park is one of Sri Lanka‚Äôs top wildlife destinations, famous for its large population of wild Asian elephants. The park‚Äôs open grasslands, scrub forests, and the scenic Udawalawe Reservoir create ideal habitats for elephants, water buffalo, spotted deer, crocodiles, and a wide range of birdlife. It‚Äôs also an excellent place to see raptors and migratory birds. With its relatively flat terrain and year-round accessibility, Udawalawe offers some of the most reliable wildlife viewing in the country. A jeep safari here provides a peaceful, authentic experience, perfect for nature lovers and photographers seeking close-up animal encounters.

We booked a mahoora tented camp in Udawalawe as part of a road trip we did in April. The booking, which was very reasonably priced, came with a tour of the Udawalawe National Park. So, this visit wasn't planned and we had no expectations .... but everything just turned out to be a perfect experience!!! Udawalawe is the seventh largest national park in Sri Lanka and is mainly known for its elephant sightings. But we heard from our guide that on extremely rare occasions there has been sightings of leopards on evening tours. We chose the morning tour. Started from the camp at 6 am and arrived at the entrance to the park by 6.30 am. [We were told the best time to see the animals is either early morning or late evening. The park opens at 6 am but I am not sure of the closing time.] While there were some vehicles, it wasn't crowded. So, that's another plus about going as early as possible. [Also it's best to avoid local school holidays and long weekends.] Heavy rains had started two days prior (which was unusual for the region though) so we didn't have much expectations of seeing any animals. [We were also told the best time to visit the park was in the dry season from July - August where large herds of elephants would converge near the reservoir.] But to our surprise we saw around 10 elephants within 100 meters from the park entrance. Thereafter, there was a bit of a dry spell with no sightings except for birds and it started raining. But nevertheless we enjoyed the ride with our guide enthusiastically pointing out various birds. [While we did get a bit wet, the weather was cool and pleasant whereas a visit in the dry season would have been hot and dusty.] Then we met another herds of elephants with two baby elephants entertaining us with their antics. We stopped for a packed breakfast halfway through and all in all spent about 3 hours in the park. While park visits can always be a hit or miss, this experience turned out to be perfect. A lot of the credit should go to the echo team of the mahoora camp for their perfect organising. [I have written a separate review on our experience there.] They were so punctual, our driver was safe and reliable, our guide was knowledgeable and enthusiastic, the breakfast was lovely and the list goes on.... While you can always book a vehicle at the park entrance, it would always be better to book a vehicle in advance ( or even through a hotel, though that might include a mark up) to ensure that you avoid crowds and arrive at a time more likely to result in elephants sightings. It must also be mentioned that compared to some time back, the safari jeeps were also in relatively good condition both in terms of emissions and safety. Udawalawe National park also offers a free tusker sighting ;) The fellow is christened "Bullet" and can be found at the electric fence running parallel to the main road a little way after the park entrance (if you are coming from Udawalawe junction side) throughout the day and almost all year around. While the locals may urge you to feed him (and while that's why he is standing there) it's best not to do so for his own good health. Udawalawe National Park also has an Elephant  Orphanage and unlike Pinnawala, they release the baby elephants back into the wild after rehabilitation. You can pay a fee and see them being fed with milk. There is one session in the morning (not sure of the timing) and one at 2.30 pm. The entrance to this place is on a turn - off a little before the park entrance when coming from the Udawalawe junction. We went for a session in July of last year. While they do good work there (there is a also a programme to adopt/ sponsor a baby elephant) i had rather ambivalent feelings about the viewing experience of the feeding (those who know would know;) hence opted not to review that particular experience....

dawalawe National Park is a national park on the boundary of Sabaragamuwa and Uva Provinces in Sri Lanka. The park was created to provide a sanctuary for wild animals displaced by the construction of the Udawalawe Reservoir on the Walawe River, as well as to protect the catchment of the reservoir. The reserve covers 30,821 hectares (119.00 sq mi) of land area and was established on 30 June 1972.[1] Before the designation of the national park, the area was used for shifting cultivation (chena farming). The farmers were gradually removed once the national park was declared. The park is 165 kilometres (103 mi) from Colombo. Udawalawe is an important habitat for water birds and Sri Lankan elephants. It is a popular tourist destination and the third-most visited park in the country.[2]

Entry fees skyrocketed about 2 weeks ago. Solo travelers pay $43USD, which is about $7USD more than two travelers entering together and so on ($43USD for individuals vs $36 USD if you're a couple). Also, as a point of reference the current entrance fee for Kruger National Park in South Africa is $27USD. $43USD is an extremely high entrance fee for any National Park in the world.  I know there's a cost savings on vehicles when you share one, but a solo traveler penalty is ridiculous. I tried to find people at the gate entrance to share a safari with. Many of the tourists were interested,  but the guides have a "mafia" type "wilderness association" and refused to let any tourists share costs. Was it worth it? Maybe once. Well, when others described "herds of elephants" in their reviews, I was expecting herds, like in Tanzania, Kenya or like other places in Africa.  I believe herds in Sri Lanka means families of elephants, which numerically speaking are smaller-- maybe 5 or 6 in a family vs 10+ in Africa. There is a good variety of wildlife-- elephants, deer, monkeys, buffalo, crocodiles, mongoose, jackals, boar, peacocks and other birds. It was nice. If you're interested in going, I eventually went with the owner of my homstay, Nalaka, +94 77 635 8192. He took me on a 4 hour jeep safari for 8,500 rp. He was great at spotting birds baby elephants, and other wildlife that other guides who denied me didn't see.

We've done safaris all over the world, including multiple countries in Africa. Lahiru was one of the best guides we have ever had! From start to finish, he was courteous, well organized and extremely knowledgeable. His animal spotting abilities are second-to-none. His extensive knowledge and deep passion for his work and Udewalawe National Park were evident every step of the way. Unlike the vast majority of other guides we saw operating during our day with Lahiru, he was always very aware of the boundaries of the animals and did everything in his power to ensure they were given enough space to feel comfortable and respected. One thing that really stood out was Lahiru's willingness to go above and beyond in terms of providing you with a real feel for the park. While all the other guides simply beelined for the elephants in a dusty convoy of 20 vehicles, Lahiru strategized the day in a way which made us feel as though we actually got to experience the park itself. We spent time driving through the back trails of the park looking not just for elephants but for all the animals Udewalawe has to offer. We saw tons of elephants as well but got to do so as an individual group, not disturbed by the mass of jeeps all going to the same place at the same time. All in all, we cannot recommend Lahiru enough. He offers a true 5-star experience and we will be absolutely be joining him for another safari if we ever return to Sri Lanka. Contact him as soon as you can as he often books well over a month in advance (and for good reason) - he's the best! Thanks Lahiru.
